entry.title: Managing Test Anxiety
entry.content:
Feeling somewhat anxious or stressed before an exam is quite normal for most students. At times the tension helps you to rise to the challenge. Do you feel some or all of the following prior to writing a test?

  • Nervousness/Nausea
  • Difficulty sleeping the night before
  • Butterflies in your stomach
  • Blanking or not being able to remember anything

These are common symptoms associated with test-writing anxiety that you can learn to manage effectively. Try some of the following strategies to calm yourself and help you to focus during exam time.

Before the Exam:

  • Accept that feeling anxious prior to a test is a normal feeling.
  • Associate with positive, focused classmates.
  • Take some time to relax before you go to bed the night before your test.
  • Arrive slightly before the exam prepared with the necessary pens, pencils, calculators or reference materials (if they are allowed).
  • Visualize your successful completion of the test.
  • Use positive self-talk such as I can do this.

During the Exam

  • Write anything you know or want to remember on the back of your exam such as formulas, steps in a process, or dates in a timeline. It serves as a reminder that you do know something.
  • Begin with a question to which you know the answer to build your self-confidence.
  • Tense and relax muscles where you feel tension. For example, raise/lower/ roll your shoulders, roll your head from side to side, or flex your fingers.
  • Concentrate on an object or spot in the room for a short period of time.
  • Focus on your breathing, slowly inhaling through your nose and exhaling through your mouth.
  • Use positive self-talk such as I am doing a good job; When I work/read carefully I can figure this out, etc.

Writing an exam is a stressful situation. There is no substitution for knowing your course material but you can do your best to remain calm, positive, and focused. When you feel in control, you will do a better job of demonstrating your understanding of the course content.

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!

entry.title: Test Response Strategies
entry.content:
There are many strategies to help you maximize your performance on quizzes, unit tests, and final exams. The following provides information on three common strategies that you may find useful.

Five-Pass Strategy

This strategy has five steps or ‘passes’ for answering exam questions:

  1. Browsing Pass – scan the entire exam; note question formats, marks for each section, instructions
  2. First Answering Pass – answer questions you know the answer to and can complete quickly; maintain a brisk pace
  3. Second Answering Pass – answer questions left during the first pass that require more effort per mark; work the questions through until you experience an impasse or it is taking too long; maintain a steady pace
  4. Third Answering Pass – complete all partial answers; guess at any true/false and multiple choice questions you have left and attempt any questions still unanswered; all questions should now have full or partial answers
  5. Review Pass – check all answers and calculations as time permits

Three-Pass Strategy

This strategy has three steps or ‘passes’ for answering exam questions; is an abbreviated version of the five pass method:

  1. Overview – scan the entire exam; note question formats, marks for each section, instructions, and questions you can complete easily and quickly
  2. Second Pass – answer all questions you can complete without too much difficulty stopping when the question becomes too challenging or is taking too much time
  3. Last Pass – answer any questions that are left; guess and provide partial answers if necessary

Problem-Solving Strategy

This strategy has four steps to work through in answering a problem; the problem can be a word problem or a calculation problem:

  1. Understand the problem – What is the question? Do I have the information I need?
  2. Develop a Plan – Have I done something similar before? Can I break the question down into smaller parts?
  3. Carry out the Plan – Is my process logical? Have I shown all of the steps in the process? Have I included the correct units of measurement?
  4. Look Back – Have I answered the question? Does my answer make sense?

When writing an exam it is important that you use strategies that work for you – strategies that you understand and can use confidently. An exam is not the time to “try something new”.

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!

entry.title: Test Writing Tips: Part 2
entry.content:
Here are the “Last Five” of the Top Ten Test Writing Tips that may help you to write a stronger exam!

  • Start with a question for which you know the answer. You do not have to start at the beginning of the test. Knowing the answer to the first question you try builds your confidence and sets a positive tone for the rest of the exam.
  • Look for clues and information in one part of the test that helps you to answer questions in another part. Useful information is often included in diagrams, charts, graphs, photos, and source information such as the year a photo was taken or where the author lived. Pictures, charts, graphs, and diagrams may provide a context for the question you are expected to answer.
  • Answer every question even if you have to guess. Leaving a question blank is guaranteed to earn you zero marks. An educated guess in a multiple choice question gives you an opportunity to ‘luck out’.
  • Read over all of your answers before you hand in your test. You want to be sure you’ve answered all the questions, that your response satisfies what was asked, and that your calculations are accurate. Where necessary include the units of measurement.
  • Finish your answers to written response or essay questions in point form if you are running out of time. This shows the marker that you have understood the question and have an organized and thoughtful response – just not enough time for complete sentences.

When writing an exam, there is no substitute for knowing your course material really well but you can bolster your performance by staying in the exam room for the entire amount of time and reviewing your answers. Take a short ‘mental break’ by rolling your head from side to side and/or shrugging your shoulders. In thinking about the overall test or reviewing specific questions, you may remember additional information to add to some of your written responses or help you with the multiple choice questions.

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!
